statement: The NCGAMI framework exhibits excessive mathematical complexity without clear practical benefits.
The practical implementation details of the quantum adiabatic optimization algorithm are unclear.
The computational complexity of implementing the sheaf cohomology calculations is not specified.
It is unclear how the model handles numerical instabilities in the quantum adiabatic optimization.
The research plan proposes a novel approach in drug-target interaction prediction, which utilizes the concept of unsupervised domain adaptation.
The authors proposed several theorems and corresponding proofs, however, almost every proof is explained with sequential steps, which are still not very trivial.

Since the main idea of this work is UDA framework for DTI, to demonstrate the effectiveness of theoretical framework itself, authors should compare their framework with other UDA frameworks, while applying them to DTI.

The Unsupervised Domain Adaptation is a long-standing research domain and numerous papers have been published, even if we narrow it down to DTI, but this study hardly reviews this profound and broad research domain, which makes the proposed method poorly motivated.
There is a disconnection between the introduction of non-commutative geometric framework and its application to deep learning models in the NCGAMI architecture.
It is totally unclear how the proposed algorithms are incorporated into the NCGAMI deep learning architecture.

There is huge gap between the proposed theoretical framework and real applications, for instance, why we should consider non-commutative geometry, how the topological space of molecular configurations is related to DTI, and what is the biological meaning of Pharmacological sheaf cohomology.
The baseline comparisons only include relatively simple models such as DeepDTA, while many important GNNs are not considered, for instance Graph transformer models and graph attention models.
